sen.e: The `Kogai` (Traditional Hairpin accessory) is decorative hairdressing implement used for lifting hair into a bun shape.

sen.e: In Japan, it was referred to as one of the '3 essential items' that were accessories to a traditional Japanese (short) sword and, was often carried along with a sword.

sen.j: 髪を掻き揚げやすいように頭部から長細い二本の足が出た形をしているか（頭部はイチョウの葉型が一般的）棒形が普通。
sen.e: To make combing easy, the combs generally had two long prongs which reached the scalp much like a rod (or prongs in a clover leaf configuration).

sen.j: 棒形のものは「棒笄」と呼ばれ、最高級品は鶴の脛の骨で作ったもので、頭痛のまじないにもなると好事家などに好まれたという。
sen.e: Hairpins in a rod like configuration were called 'rod hairpins' of which the best quality units were made of the shin bone of a crane and therefore, due to the supposed ability to ward off headache were also preferred by individuals with refined taste.

sen.j: 日本髪に欠かせない「櫛」「簪」「笄」の三点セットのうち、笄は櫛に継ぐ由来の古さを誇る。
sen.e: Japanese traditional hairstyles cannot do without a comb, ornate hairpin accessory and hairpins and, amongst these three items, the hairpin proudly follows on from the historical origins of the comb.

Japanese traditional hairstyles cannot do without the 'Kushi' (comb), the 'Kanzashi' (ornate hairpin accessory) and the 'Kogai' (hairpin) and, amongst these three items, the Kogai hairpin proudly follows on from the historical origins of the comb.

sen.e: Originally, hairpins were a practical item used to secure the topknot of a hairdo however, with the onset of more complex hairstyles in the late Edo period their usefulness diminished and, became much like an ornamental accessory.
